triggers.response: Crashes don't destroy wealth, they TRANSFER it. From the panicked to the prepared. While the fearful lose their minds, the financially educated are positioning for the transfer.
Wealth transfer happens when the crowd is losing its faith. Bitcoin's recent 15% dip illustrated it perfectly: panic sellers got squeezed while institutional money was flowing IN, not out.
Institutional money stays in the game. They run risk models that force selling when volatility spikes—not because they lost faith, but because algorithms command it. That creates the cascade we buy.
Institutions sell automatically based on risk models when volatility hits. It's mechanical, automatic, and violent. We don't fear the machine; we use its forced flows to get better entries.
When volatility spikes hit, risk models trigger a selling cascade. This disconnects price from fundamentals, creating a huge gap that leads to the inevitable snapback.
Bitcoin doesn't just recover—it SNAPS back. Every forced seller on the way down becomes a forced buyer on the way up. The system that accelerates crashes also fuels the rally.
Most investors miss the recovery because they are too busy being confused about the crash. We understand the mechanics of forced flows and position intelligently for the rally.
Dealer hedging and basis trades create mechanical pressure. When those unwound trades are put back on, they push prices higher just as violently as they pushed them lower.
Being liquidated means you were exit liquidity for the prepared. We teach you to see the mechanical flows so you stay in the trade while others are being washed out.
When algorithms say reduce exposure, they don't care about the 'why.' They just sell. That forced selling is exactly what creates the opportunity for the financially educated trader.
